Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multimedia Engineering Notebook Tools to Support Engineering Discourse in Urban Elementary School Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative, exploratory, learning strand project focuses on improving reflective decision-making among elementary school students during the planning and re-design activities of the engineering design process. Five teacher researchers in three elementary schools provide the classroom laboratories for the study. Specified units from Engineering is Elementary, a well-studied curriculum, provide the engineering content. In year one, the qualitative research observes student discourse as students develop designs. Based on the results, a paper engineering note book with prompts is designed for use in year two while a digital notebook is developed. In year three, the students use the digital notebook to develop their designs and redesigns.

The research identifies patterns of language that contribute to the reflective discourse and determines how the paper and electronic versions of the notebook improve the discourse. An advisory committee provides advice and evaluation. The notebooks are described in conference proceedings and made available online.

This work synthesizes what is known about the use of the notebooks in science and engineering education at the elementary school and investigates how to improve their use through digital media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The major goals of this project were to: 1) Identify and describe the patterns of discourse that constitute reflective decision-making in engineering and the discursive resources for reflective decision-making that urban K-5 students bring to engineering design processes; 2) Identify synergies and gaps between elementary students' and engineering practitioners' decision-making, and work with teacher partners to develop paper-based and digital engineering notebook tools that support the discourse practices associated with reflective decision-making for engineering design: 3) Explore how the engineering notebook tools support students' reflective decision-making and engineering design solutions in a pilot group of urban elementary school classrooms; 4) Use the results of the classroom studies to produce and disseminate a revised set of engineering notebook tools for elementary students. 

The project utilized design-based research in collaboration with five elementary teachers in a large urban school district over a five-year span. During this time engineering units were implemented in each classroom. The collaborative research teams consisted of two university engineering educators, one university literacy educator, two graduate assistants, along with the five teachers.  Qualitative data collected at the sites included: video and audio recordings of classroom interactions, artifacts such as photos of environmental print, digital copies of student work, district and state policy documents, curriculum materials, and audio recordings of meetings of the research team. An iterative process of analysis of this data focused on questions related to the projects' goals. Findings supported adaptations to subsequent implementation of engineering units that continued over the five-year period.  

Intellectual Merit: Analysis of classroom discourse revealed elementary students engaged in six elements of reflective decision making during planning and redesign phases of the engineering design cycle (Wendell, Wright, & Paugh, 2017). Additional analysis of classroom discourse highlighted: 1) ways in which students from historically marginalized groups conceptualized urban engineering spaces as sites for risk management that informed the quality of their participation (Wright, Wendell, & Paugh, 2018); 2) how interactions and writing of an English Learner provided a view of the engineering design space as a site for linguistic agency linked to productive engineering accomplishments (Paugh, Wendell, & Wright, 2018); and 3) what epistemic interactions with digital notebook tools reveal about productive means for structuring whole class design talks around sequences of prototypes over time, resulting in student-generated sets of design recommendations rather than products (Wendell, Andrews, & Paugh, 2019).  

Broader Outcomes: The design-based exploratory funding supported the production of a set of digital notebooking tools which are currently available free of charge for educators at: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/design-keeper/id1333514520. These findings also informed the development of literacy lesson plans useful for integrating literacy practices within engineering units of study (Paugh & Wendell, under review).
